metadata.subject: physics
metadata.topicName: Uniform Circular Motion in a Horizontal Plane
metadata.dotPoint: investigate and analyse theoretically and practically the uniform circular motion of an object moving in a horizontal plane: Fnet = mv¬≤/r, including: a vehicle moving around a circular road, a vehicle moving around a banked track, an object on the end of a string

centripetal_direction.name: Centripetal Force Direction
centripetal_direction.correct: Centripetal force ALWAYS points toward the centre of the circular path. It is perpendicular to velocity and causes the direction of motion to change.

outward from centre.error: You're describing centrifugal 'force', which is a fictitious force in a rotating frame.
outward from centre.fix: Real centripetal force points INWARD. The 'outward' feeling is your body's inertia resisting the inward acceleration.
outward from centre.action: Spin a ball on a string. Which way does the string pull the ball? Toward your hand (the centre).

tangent to the circle.error: That's the direction of velocity, not centripetal force.
tangent to the circle.fix: Velocity is tangential. Centripetal force is perpendicular to velocity, pointing to centre.
tangent to the circle.action: Draw a circle, draw velocity tangent at a point, then draw centripetal force 90¬∞ to it (toward centre).

in the direction of motion.error: Centripetal force is perpendicular to motion, not parallel.
in the direction of motion.fix: A force in the direction of motion would speed up the object. Centripetal force changes direction, not speed.
in the direction of motion.action: In uniform circular motion, speed is constant. What's changing? Direction. Force must be perpendicular.

opposite to velocity.error: That would slow the object down, not change its direction.
opposite to velocity.fix: Centripetal force is perpendicular to velocity, causing direction change without speed change.
opposite to velocity.action: Think: what direction force would change your path without slowing you?

persistent.gap: You're confusing the direction of centripetal force with other vectors.
persistent.action: Draw 5 circles with objects at different points. At each point, draw velocity (tangent) and centripetal force (to centre). They must be perpendicular.

centripetal_formula.name: Centripetal Force Formula
centripetal_formula.correct: Centripetal force equals mass times velocity squared, divided by radius: Fc = mv¬≤/r. Velocity is squared, making the relationship non-linear.

Fc = mv/r.fix: Fc = mv¬≤/r. The v is squared. Double the speed ‚Üí quadruple the centripetal force.
Fc = mv/r.action: Check units: m(m/s)¬≤/m = m(m¬≤/s¬≤)/m = m¬∑m/s¬≤ = kg¬∑m/s¬≤ = N ‚úì

Fc = mv¬≤r.error: Radius should be in the denominator.
Fc = mv¬≤r.fix: Fc = mv¬≤/r. Larger radius means LESS centripetal force for same speed.
Fc = mv¬≤r.action: Think: a gentle curve (large r) needs less force than a tight curve (small r).

Fc = mvr.error: Wrong formula entirely. Velocity should be squared and r in denominator.
Fc = mvr.fix: Fc = mv¬≤/r. This is mvr would give units of kg¬∑m¬≤/s, not Newtons.
Fc = mvr.action: Dimensional analysis: force must have units of N = kg¬∑m/s¬≤.

Fc = mr/v¬≤.fix: Fc = mv¬≤/r. More speed needs more force. Larger radius needs less force.
Fc = mr/v¬≤.action: Does it make sense that going faster requires LESS force to turn? No.

persistent.gap: You haven't memorised the centripetal force formula correctly.
persistent.action: Write Fc = mv¬≤/r ten times. Then calculate Fc for v, 2v, and 3v to see the squared relationship.

centripetal_acceleration.name: Centripetal Acceleration
centripetal_acceleration.correct: Centripetal acceleration equals velocity squared divided by radius: ac = v¬≤/r. Direction is always toward the centre of the circle.

ac = v/r.fix: ac = v¬≤/r. Acceleration depends on v squared.
ac = v/r.action: Double the speed ‚Üí quadruple the centripetal acceleration.

ac = vr.error: Wrong relationship. r should be in denominator.
ac = vr.fix: ac = v¬≤/r. Tighter curves (smaller r) mean larger acceleration.
ac = vr.action: Check: does a tighter turn feel like more or less acceleration?

ac = r/v¬≤.error: Inverted. Larger radius should give smaller acceleration.
ac = r/v¬≤.fix: ac = v¬≤/r. Gentle curves (large r) have small acceleration.
ac = r/v¬≤.action: A nearly straight path (r ‚Üí ‚àû) should have nearly zero centripetal acceleration.

ac = 2v/r.error: There's no factor of 2 and v should be squared.
ac = 2v/r.fix: ac = v¬≤/r exactly. The 2 doesn't belong.
ac = 2v/r.action: This might be confusion with the derivative. The formula is simply v¬≤/r.

persistent.gap: You're not clear on the centripetal acceleration formula.
persistent.action: Derive from F = ma: if Fc = mv¬≤/r and Fc = mac, then ac = v¬≤/r.

uniform_circular_motion.name: Uniform Circular Motion Definition
uniform_circular_motion.correct: Uniform circular motion means constant SPEED but changing VELOCITY. Speed (magnitude) is constant; velocity (vector) changes because direction changes.

constant velocity.error: Velocity is NOT constant‚Äîits direction is continuously changing.
constant velocity.fix: Speed is constant. Velocity changes because direction changes.
constant velocity.action: Velocity is a vector. In circular motion, the direction changes constantly.

constant acceleration.error: Acceleration magnitude is constant, but direction changes (always toward centre).
constant acceleration.fix: Centripetal acceleration has constant magnitude but changing direction.
constant acceleration.action: Acceleration is a vector too. It always points to centre, so its direction changes.

no acceleration.error: There IS acceleration‚Äîcentripetal acceleration toward the centre.
no acceleration.fix: Constant speed ‚â† no acceleration. Changing direction requires acceleration.
no acceleration.action: Newton's First Law: changing velocity requires a net force, hence acceleration.

changing speed.fix: Uniform circular motion = constant speed around the circle.
changing speed.action: If speed changed, it wouldn't be 'uniform' circular motion.

persistent.action: Define: speed = |v| (magnitude only), velocity = v (magnitude AND direction). In UCM, |v| is constant, v is not.

period_and_speed.name: Circular Speed and Period
period_and_speed.correct: Circular speed equals circumference divided by period: v = 2œÄr/T. One complete revolution covers distance 2œÄr in time T.

v = œÄr/T.error: Missing factor of 2. Circumference is 2œÄr, not œÄr.
v = œÄr/T.action: œÄr is only half the circumference. You need the full circle.

v = 2œÄrT.fix: v = distance/time = 2œÄr/T. Longer period means slower speed.
v = 2œÄrT.action: If T is large (slow rotation), speed should be small.

v = 2œÄ/rT.error: r should be in numerator with 2œÄ.
v = 2œÄ/rT.fix: v = 2œÄr/T. Larger radius means larger speed for same period.
v = 2œÄ/rT.action: The outer edge of a merry-go-round moves faster than the centre.

v = r/T.fix: The distance around is 2œÄr, not just r.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly applying the speed = distance/time formula to circular motion.
persistent.action: Remember: one revolution covers 2œÄr metres in T seconds. v = 2œÄr/T.

friction_provides_centripetal.name: Friction as Centripetal Force on Flat Road
friction_provides_centripetal.correct: On a flat circular road, static friction between tyres and road provides the centripetal force. Friction acts toward the centre of the turn.

normal force.error: Normal force is vertical on a flat road, but centripetal force is horizontal.
normal force.fix: On a flat road: normal force is vertical (balances weight), friction is horizontal (provides centripetal force).
normal force.action: Draw FBD: weight down, normal up, friction toward centre (horizontal).

weight.error: Weight acts vertically downward, not toward the centre of the turn.
weight.fix: Weight is balanced by normal force. Friction provides the horizontal centripetal force.
weight.action: The centre of the turn is to the side, not below. Weight doesn't point there.

engine force.error: Engine force maintains speed, not circular path.
engine force.fix: Driving force from engine is tangential. Friction sideways provides centripetal force.
engine force.action: Even coasting (no engine), you need friction to turn.

centrifugal force.error: Centrifugal force is fictitious‚Äînot a real force in an inertial frame.
centrifugal force.fix: The real force is friction acting toward the centre (centripetal).
centrifugal force.action: In physics, we analyse from an inertial frame. The real force is centripetal (inward).

persistent.gap: You're not identifying which force provides centripetal force on a flat road.
persistent.action: Draw FBD of car turning on flat road. Identify horizontal forces. Only friction points toward turn centre.

banked_track_normal.name: Banked Track - Normal Force Component
banked_track_normal.formula: N sin Œ∏ = mv¬≤/r (at design speed)
banked_track_normal.correct: On a banked track at design speed, the horizontal component of the normal force (N sin Œ∏) provides the centripetal force. No friction is needed.

friction provides centripetal.error: At design speed on a properly banked track, friction is zero.
friction provides centripetal.fix: Banking tilts the normal force so its horizontal component provides centripetal force.
friction provides centripetal.action: That's WHY we bank tracks‚Äîto not rely on friction for turning.

full normal force.error: Only the horizontal COMPONENT of normal force acts as centripetal.
full normal force.fix: N sin Œ∏ is the horizontal component. N cos Œ∏ balances weight.
full normal force.action: Resolve N into components: horizontal (centripetal) and vertical (balances mg).

weight component.error: Weight is vertical. On a horizontal circular path, centripetal is horizontal.
weight component.fix: The normal force is tilted, so it has a horizontal component. Weight is always vertical.
weight component.action: Draw vectors: weight straight down, normal perpendicular to banked surface.

vertical component of normal.error: That's N cos Œ∏, which balances weight, not centripetal.
vertical component of normal.fix: N cos Œ∏ = mg (vertical balance). N sin Œ∏ = mv¬≤/r (centripetal).
vertical component of normal.action: Horizontal component points to circle centre. That's centripetal.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly resolving forces on a banked track.
persistent.action: Draw FBD: tilted normal force, resolve into N cos Œ∏ (vertical) and N sin Œ∏ (horizontal toward centre).

design_speed.name: Design Speed of Banked Track
design_speed.correct: Design speed is the speed at which a vehicle can travel around a banked track with no friction: v = ‚àö(rg tan Œ∏). At this speed, the banking alone provides centripetal force.

v = rg tan Œ∏.fix: v = ‚àö(rg tan Œ∏). The v¬≤ in centripetal formula leads to square root when solving for v.
v = rg tan Œ∏.action: From mv¬≤/r = mg tan Œ∏, solve for v: v¬≤ = rg tan Œ∏, so v = ‚àö(rg tan Œ∏).

v = ‚àö(rg/tan Œ∏).error: tan Œ∏ should be in numerator, not denominator.
v = ‚àö(rg/tan Œ∏).fix: v = ‚àö(rg tan Œ∏). Steeper bank (larger Œ∏) ‚Üí faster design speed.
v = ‚àö(rg/tan Œ∏).action: Does a steeper bank allow faster or slower turns? Faster.

v = ‚àö(rg sin Œ∏).error: It's tan Œ∏, not sin Œ∏.
v = ‚àö(rg sin Œ∏).fix: tan Œ∏ comes from the force balance: N sin Œ∏ / N cos Œ∏ = tan Œ∏.
v = ‚àö(rg sin Œ∏).action: Derive: N sin Œ∏ = mv¬≤/r and N cos Œ∏ = mg. Divide to get tan Œ∏ = v¬≤/rg.

v = ‚àö(mg tan Œ∏).error: Should be rg, not mg. Mass cancels out.
v = ‚àö(mg tan Œ∏).fix: v = ‚àö(rg tan Œ∏). Note: design speed doesn't depend on mass.
v = ‚àö(mg tan Œ∏).action: All vehicles have same design speed on a given banked curve.

persistent.gap: You haven't derived or memorised the design speed formula.
persistent.action: Derive from N sin Œ∏ = mv¬≤/r and N cos Œ∏ = mg. Divide equations and solve for v.

design_angle.name: Design Angle of Banked Track
design_angle.correct: The design angle is the banking angle needed for a given speed: Œ∏ = tan‚Åª¬π(v¬≤/rg). Faster speeds or tighter curves need steeper banking.

Œ∏ = tan‚Åª¬π(rg/v¬≤).error: Inverted. Higher speed needs steeper angle, not shallower.
Œ∏ = tan‚Åª¬π(rg/v¬≤).fix: Œ∏ = tan‚Åª¬π(v¬≤/rg). v¬≤ in numerator means faster ‚Üí steeper angle.
Œ∏ = tan‚Åª¬π(rg/v¬≤).action: Race tracks are banked more steeply because cars go faster.

Œ∏ = sin‚Åª¬π(v¬≤/rg).fix: The tan comes from the ratio of force components.
Œ∏ = sin‚Åª¬π(v¬≤/rg).action: tan Œ∏ = opposite/adjacent = (N sin Œ∏)/(N cos Œ∏) = (mv¬≤/r)/(mg).

Œ∏ = v¬≤/rg.fix: tan Œ∏ = v¬≤/rg, so Œ∏ = tan‚Åª¬π(v¬≤/rg).
Œ∏ = v¬≤/rg.action: v¬≤/rg gives tan Œ∏, not Œ∏ itself. Need inverse function.

Œ∏ = tan‚Åª¬π(v/rg).fix: Œ∏ = tan‚Åª¬π(v¬≤/rg). The square comes from centripetal formula.
Œ∏ = tan‚Åª¬π(v/rg).action: Remember Fc = mv¬≤/r has v¬≤. That carries through to the angle.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting the angle formula to the force balance.
persistent.action: Derive: tan Œ∏ = v¬≤/rg from N sin Œ∏ = mv¬≤/r and N cos Œ∏ = mg. Then Œ∏ = tan‚Åª¬π(v¬≤/rg).

conical_pendulum.name: Conical Pendulum
conical_pendulum.formula: T sin Œ∏ = mv¬≤/r, T cos Œ∏ = mg
conical_pendulum.correct: For a mass on a string in horizontal circular motion: tension's horizontal component (T sin Œ∏) provides centripetal force, vertical component (T cos Œ∏) balances weight.

tension provides centripetal directly.error: Only the horizontal COMPONENT of tension acts as centripetal force.
tension provides centripetal directly.fix: Tension is at an angle. T sin Œ∏ is horizontal (centripetal), T cos Œ∏ is vertical.
tension provides centripetal directly.action: The string isn't horizontal‚Äîit angles up to the pivot point.

weight provides centripetal.error: Weight is vertical; centripetal force for horizontal circle is horizontal.
weight provides centripetal.fix: Weight is balanced by T cos Œ∏. T sin Œ∏ provides centripetal force.
weight provides centripetal.action: The mass circles horizontally. Centripetal is horizontal, toward the vertical axis.

T = mv¬≤/r.error: That would be true only if string were horizontal (Œ∏ = 90¬∞).
T = mv¬≤/r.fix: T sin Œ∏ = mv¬≤/r. Only the horizontal component is centripetal.
T = mv¬≤/r.action: Tension is larger than centripetal force because it also supports weight.

T sin Œ∏ = mg.error: Swapped components. sin goes with centripetal, cos with weight.
T sin Œ∏ = mg.fix: T sin Œ∏ = mv¬≤/r (horizontal centripetal), T cos Œ∏ = mg (vertical balance).
T sin Œ∏ = mg.action: Draw the geometry: Œ∏ from vertical means sin Œ∏ gives horizontal, cos Œ∏ gives vertical.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly resolving tension in a conical pendulum.
persistent.action: Draw FBD with T at angle Œ∏ from vertical. Resolve: T cos Œ∏ = mg (vertical), T sin Œ∏ = mv¬≤/r (horizontal).

tension_magnitude.name: Tension in Conical Pendulum
tension_magnitude.correct: Tension magnitude can be found from T cos Œ∏ = mg, giving T = mg/cos Œ∏. Tension is always greater than weight.

T = mg.error: Tension exceeds weight because it also provides centripetal force.
T = mg.fix: T cos Œ∏ = mg, so T = mg/cos Œ∏. Since cos Œ∏ < 1, T > mg.
T = mg.action: The string must support weight AND pull toward centre.

T = mg cos Œ∏.error: Inverted. Tension is mg divided by cos Œ∏.
T = mg cos Œ∏.fix: From T cos Œ∏ = mg: T = mg/cos Œ∏.
T = mg cos Œ∏.action: If T = mg cos Œ∏, tension would be LESS than weight. That can't support the mass.

T = mg sin Œ∏.fix: T cos Œ∏ = mg (vertical balance), so T = mg/cos Œ∏.
T = mg sin Œ∏.action: sin Œ∏ relates to horizontal component, not weight balance.

T = mv¬≤/r.error: That's only the horizontal component of tension.
T = mv¬≤/r.fix: T sin Œ∏ = mv¬≤/r. Full tension is T = mg/cos Œ∏ or T = ‚àö[(mg)¬≤ + (mv¬≤/r)¬≤].
T = mv¬≤/r.action: Use Pythagoras: T¬≤ = (T cos Œ∏)¬≤ + (T sin Œ∏)¬≤ = (mg)¬≤ + (mv¬≤/r)¬≤.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly calculating tension magnitude.
persistent.action: Method 1: T = mg/cos Œ∏. Method 2: T = ‚àö[(mg)¬≤ + (mv¬≤/r)¬≤]. Practice both.

radius_vs_length.name: Radius vs String Length
radius_vs_length.correct: In a conical pendulum, radius of circular path r = L sin Œ∏, where L is string length and Œ∏ is angle from vertical.

r = L.error: Radius equals string length only if string is horizontal (Œ∏ = 90¬∞).
r = L.fix: r = L sin Œ∏. The mass traces a circle smaller than the string length.
r = L.action: Draw the geometry: string L at angle Œ∏, horizontal distance (radius) is L sin Œ∏.

r = L cos Œ∏.error: cos Œ∏ gives vertical distance from pivot, not radius.
r = L cos Œ∏.fix: r = L sin Œ∏ (horizontal), h = L cos Œ∏ (vertical drop from pivot).

r = L tan Œ∏.error: Wrong trig function for finding the opposite side.
r = L tan Œ∏.fix: From right triangle: r = L sin Œ∏.
r = L tan Œ∏.action: tan Œ∏ = opposite/adjacent = r/(L cos Œ∏). So r = L cos Œ∏ tan Œ∏ = L sin Œ∏.

r = L/sin Œ∏.fix: r = L sin Œ∏. For small angles, r is small. sin Œ∏ < 1, so r < L.
r = L/sin Œ∏.action: The radius must be smaller than the string length.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly relating radius to string length geometrically.
persistent.action: Draw the triangle: hypotenuse = L, angle Œ∏ from vertical, horizontal side (radius) = L sin Œ∏.
